Link to today's office hour+ [1]. Much was discussed. Some things were resolved. Some things are still unresolved.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-placement/%23openstack-placement.2019-06-12.log.html#t2019-06-12T14:56:00"}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-13 04:56:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-13 08:42:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Eric's comments at http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-placement/%23openstack-placement.2019-06-12.log.html#t2019-06-12T21:20:48 plus tetsuro's latest points about CPUs on NICs, and the office hours discussion that created the term "solution path" help crystallise a few things.

Especially with regard to the distinction between request-wide and group-oriented query params.

The nic cpu thing seems to kill flow-down for traits, but for aggregates we may need to continue thinking, because of the containership/target notions discussed during office hours.

I think I can be convinced that some kind of 'already_found_solution_paths_(requires|member_of)=(FOO|!FOO)' is a legit thing for solving [1], but it makes me a bit sad because that's how unsuffixed 'required' reads to me. When I make a query that has 'required' in it, it reads as "I need a target that has FOO" or "make sure my host as FOO".

A question worth asking is: If we added a 'already_found..' why wouldn't I use that all the time instead of unsuffixed required? And if that's the case maybe unsuffixed required _is_ (that is should act like, but with the name required) 'already_found..'?

I know if feels like we are belabouring this stuff, but it feels like each day we uncover a new wrinkle, and while that is still happening it is uncomfortable to commit to anything. Those wrinkles have proved educational and illuminating.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-placement/%23openstack-placement.2019-06-12.log.html#t2019-06-12T21:20:48-2'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-13 09:28:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

My brain dump based on yesterday's office hours discussion:
Theory1: In openstack we have two kind of traits today:
* trait that defines a property of a resource class
  e.g.: HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING -> talks about the property of the [VP]CPU resource, trait attached to NUMA RP or root RP
  other examples:
  * CUSTOM_PHYSNET_1, CUSTOM_VNIC_TYPE_DIRECT -> NET_BW_EGR_KILOBIT_PER_SEC
  * STORAGE_DISK_SSD -> DISK_GB
  * HW_NIC_SRIOV_TRUSTED -> SRIOV_NET_VF
  * COMPUTE_VOLUME_MULTI_ATTACH -> a cinder related disk resource not yet managed in placement. Until it is not managed in placement this trait could belong to the second group instead.


* trait that defines the capability of the compute host /  hypervisor but does not tight to a specific resource the request consumes
  e.g.: COMPUTE_TRUSTED_CERT -> virt driver capability that does not connected to any specific consumable on the host
  DEVICE_TAGGING -> virt capability
  COMPUTE_IMAGE_TYPE_*

Theory2:
* The resource specific traits (first group) has definite place in the tree (the RP that provides the related resource) and requesting these traits only meaningful if the related resource is also requested. e.g.: required1=CUSTOM_PHYSNET_1 is meaningless without resources1=NET_BW_EGR_KILOBIT_PER_SEC:1000.
* In the other hand traits in the second group tend to simply be on the root RP as they are not related to any particular RP. Also these traits can be required without requesting any specific resource.


Eric's example:

R() -  A(rc:X, trait:FOO)
 \  -  B(rc:X, trait:BAR)

?resources=X&required_1=FOO

* If in this example FOO and BAR are from the first group, relating to resource class X then the ?resources=X&required_1=FOO query is not meaningful to me as it does not express the connection between X and the FO
O trait and therefore leads to wrong results like A -> FOO + B -> X.

* If in this example FOO is from the second trait group, then the example RP model is faulty as non resource related traits tend to be on the root RP.


Mapping Eric's example to some real life situation with:

R() - NUMA0(rc:VCPU, trait:HW_CPU_X86_AVX)
 \  - NUMA1(rc:VCPU, trait:HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING)

?resources=VCPU:1&required_1=HW_CPU_X86_AVX  

I think this request is wrong as the client knows that HW_CPU_X86_AVX is a property of the VCPU resource so it should request the rc and the trait in the same group.

For example the above query structure cannot be extended to two different type of cpu resources without start using the good formulation:  
  ?resources_1=VCPU:1&required_1=HW_CPU_X86_AVX&resources_2:VCPU:1&required_2=HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING


In the other hand if FOO is mapped to COMPUTE_TRUSTED_CERT then the tree feels wrong:
R() - NUMA0(rc:VCPU, trait:COMPUTE_TRUSTED_CERT)
 \  - NUMA1(rc:VCPU, trait:HW_CPU_HYPERTHREADING)


So my current view is that placement cannot be made generic and supporting both type of traits meaningfully without distinguishing them. Can we rely on the client not to create wrong trees or sends wrong queries (as in the above examples)? Unfortunately placement cannot detect that the tree / query is wrong as for placement the two types of traits are indistinguishable."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-13 13:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

I think we're getting somewhere with "two different classes of traits" + "group-oriented vs request-wide query params" + "need a late trait(/agg) filter" + what tetsuro refers to as (B) (which was a use case, not a solution, but I think he meant "we only need a special case to solve (B)"). As follows:

The only use case we care about in the context of this discussion is "ROOT must satisfy {+/- trait/agg}, regardless of whether ROOT contributes resource" [1].

The expression of ^ is "request-wide" thing.

We could think of ^ as applying to "the solution path". That means we have to introduce the "solution path" concept itself, which involves some form of "flow".
- We would rather not actually "flow down" traits, for reasons previously discussed [2].
- We could instead conceptualize "solution path" as more of a "flow up" - that is, we implicitly include all ancestry lines of providers otherwise involved in the solution.

or

We could ditch the "solution path" concept and simply state that "ROOT is always implicitly involved in the solution".

I agree with cdent's sadness that the unsuffixed "required" *feels* like the thing that should convey this meaning, but "required" is already taken. So we have two sucky choices: overload/redefine "required"; or come up with a new key. But if we go with the above ("ROOT is always involved" rather than "solution path"), then we can simplify from 'already_found_solution_paths_(requires|member_of)' to 'root_(required|member_of)'.

So, assuming we can agree on the problem space as distilled & stated above, I'm proposing the following two alternatives:

- Overload the meaning of unsuffixed "required" and "member_of". Today, they mean "providers of unsuffixed `resources` must also satisfy these trait/agg requirements". Proposed, they mean "providers of unsuffixed `resources` OR THE ROOT PROVIDER must also satisfy these trait/agg requirements" [3] [4].
- Introduce `root_(required|member_of)`, which are request-wide query params, which perform a distinct check on the root provider only [5].

[1] Any other use cases can be solved via proper modeling+requesting (paraphrasing gibi: make sure your resource-specific trait is on the provider of that trait, and request that trait in the same group as that resource); or via resourceless+same_subtree (this addresses NUMA_ROOT or DEVICE_ROOT cases); or via other mechanisms already extant in master. (We should probably triple-check that this is true before we pull the trigger on anything.)
[2] like tetsuro's "CPU on a NIC" thing; and gibi's "resource-related traits should stick [only] with their resources".
[3] Note that this definition works when the unsuffixed group is resourceless too.
[4] Um, for the negative cases s/OR/AND/ in your head.
[5] Note that in this form the check could actually be done *first*, which may be a nontrivial performance boon.'}, {'account_id': 7166, 'date': '2019-06-13 16:23:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(17 comments)

A few comments on the formatting of the spec, but not worth -1ing them. IF people are cool with a FUP, I'm okay with +2ing this spec."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-13 20:21:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(10 comments)

Thank you for reviewing, Sylvain.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-14 15:48:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-14 16:35:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-14 16:44:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-16 09:36:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Feedback to Eric's proposals in PS4;

 > ‚Äúproviders of unsuffixed `resources` OR THE ROOT PROVIDER
 > must also satisfy these trait/agg requirements‚Äù

This will have a change in the existing API (i.e. with already supported query). Not sure we want to have microversion for that. Plus, personally I don‚Äôt love ‚Äúimplicit‚Äù trait/aggregate ideas as I said in [1].

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004909.html

 > Introduce `root_required`, which are request-wide query params,
 > which perform a distinct check on the root provider only.

This is clearer and is my preference between the two, but why request-wide? Being request-wide, it‚Äôs a bit confusing to define if this means either ‚Äúanchor_root_required‚Äù or ‚Äúroot_required‚Äù or both. Please also refer to my comments in [2].

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/665492/4/placement/tests/functional/gabbits/allocation-candidates-root_required.yaml@84"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-16 12:44:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> why request-wide? 

So that I can specify it without worrying which of my request groups will be satisfied by sharing or non-sharing providers. E.g. in a model where DISK_GB exists both on the host and on a sharing provider.

> Being request-wide, it‚Äôs a bit confusing to define if this means either ‚Äúanchor_root_required‚Äù or ‚Äúroot_required‚Äù or both.

I agree about the confusion. I definitely mean "anchor_root_required". I'm (at least currently) not interested in the use case where a) sharing providers are nested and b) I care about traits on *their* roots.

That being the case, do you agree it makes sense for it to be request-wide?

 Let's find a way, either through naming or docs, to make this clear.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-17 09:55:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> That being the case, do you agree it makes sense for it to be request-wide?

Yes. Thanks for the clarification.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-17 11:20:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> > Being request-wide, it‚Äôs a bit confusing to define if this means
 > either ‚Äúanchor_root_required‚Äù or ‚Äúroot_required‚Äù or both.

Are "anchor" and "target" synonyms?'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-17 14:29:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Explicit tend to be better than implicit so the new request-wide-required key works for me. I'm happy to ignore the case when only a subtree root has a trait but no resources. I don't see any real examples today for that.

Do we want to specify request-wide-forbidden as well?"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:35:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

This patch set hopefully incorporates the conclusions of all the
discussions since the previous one. In particular:

- Describes "resource vs. provider traits"
- Describes "group-specific vs. request-wide query parameters"
- Suggests what we should do about resourceless *without* same_subtree
  (response requested please).
- Adds ``root_required``.

Specific questions answered:

> Are "anchor" and "target" synonyms?

I don't have a definition of "target" in my head. It's not a term used
in the docs anywhere; and in the code it's used in a very localized way
to refer to "whatever thingy we're dealing with in this method".

By now I strongly believe that there is no single word that, without
additional explanation, embodies the concept of "root of the non-sharing
tree involved in the allocation candidate". ("host" comes close, but
that's a specific nova-centric instance of the idea.) So since "anchor"
is what's already being used in the code, we might as well go with it
within the dev team. But we should continue to refrain as long as
possible from needing that term to be user-facing.

> Do we want to specify request-wide-forbidden as well?

This is incorporated in ``root_required``, which accepts the ``!``
prefix on trait names just like ``required[$S]``.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:28:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

LGTM! Thanks Eric!'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2019-06-19 09:11:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:40:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 14:59:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> This patch set hopefully incorporates the conclusions of all the
 > discussions since the previous one. In particular:

Will respond in stages. This is before actually reading the spec, just wanted to get to a particular question.

 > > Are "anchor" and "target" synonyms?
 > 
 > I don't have a definition of "target" in my head. It's not a term
 > used
 > in the docs anywhere; and in the code it's used in a very localized
 > way
 > to refer to "whatever thingy we're dealing with in this method".

Your (and my) confusion is part of why I asked. I've never understood what "anchor" means in the code but it appears to mean "the place where a request workload lands, as identified by the root provider id of the non-sharing provider". Is that right?

External to the code "target" (or something else) makes more sense for "a place where this workload might land (as identified by the root provider)" than anchor. An anchor is a thing other providers in the current tree care about.

Target is a thing the client cares about: Where I can _place_ this.

So, based on that, it might be they are not quite synonyms but might both be useful. If we want to use "anchor" as the term for both I'm happy with that if we want to settle that way.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-06-19 15:24:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

We seem to be nearing consensus and also seem to pushed the number of invested people down to 4. That feels risky but I don't think there's an alternative.

We may find ourselves in some corners with dragons. In fact, I think it is inevitable, but we've been there before and survived. We need to keep things moving and deal with the warts as they happen.

I'm still a bit sad about adding yet more syntax, but it's good that we are keeping it contained to what I consider "specialist" use cases and existing simple cases will continue to work as is.

I want to read it again tomorrow, but I'm happy enough to signal a +1 to just say "yeah"'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2019-06-19 16:56:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

commit_message:
Spec for nested magic 1

This is a spec for several nested features which has been split
off from the original spec for nested magic [1] in an effort to
not delay progress on these features while 'can_split' is being
discussed.

This spec describes a cluster of Placement API work to support several
interrelated use cases for Train around:

* Modeling complex trees such as NUMA layouts, multiple devices,
  networks.
* Requesting affinity (in the NUMA sense) between/among the various
  providers/allocations in allocation candidates against such layouts.
* Describing granular groups more richly to facilitate the above.
* Requesting candidates based on traits/aggregates that are not
  necessarily associated with resources.

In particular, it describes the new GET /allocation_candidates
features:

* arbitrary group suffixes
* same_subtree query parameter
* resourceless request groups
* root_required, root_member_of

[1] I7c00b06e85879ab1bf877ce32979e8cc898bfd9e

Co-Authored-By: Eric Fried <openstack@fried.cc>
Change-Id: I55973aa7de4a85b63dff4a7d1afb6c36796af71a
Story: #2005575
Task: #30949

commit_message:
Fix network pool deletion method

This patch ensures that available_ports_pools dict structure is not
modified to be a list when ports are deleted while running the
network pool deletion method. This ensures further iterations on that
dict will not fail.

Closes-Bug: 1832838
Change-Id: I6f19724fe0dabc00d4fae5097301f7ab46a91483
(cherry picked from commit 19045416455c16c44fc424bb33048dbea2bb0301)

commit_message:
Allows to collect neutron agent wrappers and kill-scripts

It's always good to keep them for debugging purpose, especially nowadays
when we have both podman and docker.

It consists in a few bash scripts, meaning it shouldn't be more than a
few k.

Change-Id: Ic174d27fde130a168707da1258bac7283195b60c

commit_message:
Add a variable to configure repos disabled in base CentOS image

[1] disabled CentOS Ceph Nautilus repo for Stein.
It turned out to be a problem for TripleO ([2])
which does not use upstream Ceph repo and actually
relies on CentOS Ceph Nautilus repo.
We did not leave the option to override our customization.
This patch adds a customizable variable to base CentOS image:
centos_yum_repos_to_disable

[1] https://review.opendev.org/651601
[2] https://review.opendev.org/664244

Change-Id: I867ca75cafe853b206beae2f81dfb79b62d05557
Signed-off-by: Rados≈Çaw Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Remove redundant group host setup

It seems that all the code path that ends up calling [1] goes through
[2] before so setting up group host at [1] is redundant.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c7e9e667426a6d88d396a59cb40d30763a3265f9/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L944-L950
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/c7e9e667426a6d88d396a59cb40d30763a3265f9/nova/scheduler/utils.py#L996-L1000

Change-Id: I745aecb008f0867fcda2d3d2c7691621dd8f6168
Closes-Bug: #1788527

commit_message:
Remove ping_me script

We've moved to managing the ping list in the meeting agenda on the
wiki instead. To avoid confusion, let's remove the old script. If
we find that we need to revive it in the future we can always pull
it from the git history.

Change-Id: I8e5c4efbc26110ae87aae7c4661f67bb1c5f9c26

commit_message:
Remove deprecated compute.v2.fixedip/floatingip

These were deprecated in these changes:

Ic0dd22ca6fb7b7bc3e820fd5a14d7c551e7ab963

Ica07ccf92a76c21fd5608ecaff86ff7c4d96f5a0

The related novaclient changes have been removed
in the novaclient 10.0.0 release, so it's time to
also remove these from openstackclient.

Change-Id: I6a2c4406dc3701d8af99ed7f714c077a47a279ce
Related-Bug: #1745795

An other point is how operators are going to provision this option?

- For public cloud they will probably continue to use host aggregates, that because they have enough hypervisors and they want something easy to manage.

- For private cloud they will start an instance to fit the free pCPUs and make running all the low performance processes on it.

My point of view is that, you are going to add complexity in the scheduling, migration and operators configurations for no real use-case. I would recommend to do not accept such spec or please let me know the point I have missed.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:48:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2018-02-23 12:54:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

Ok if you really want it... but i'm still not convinced of the use-cases, for me there is no use-cases, I don't see public cloud doing such "micro" partitioning and users running NFV dedicate the whole server for high perf applications, then using one or two VMs to run specific low performance apps. So for me it's not clear who are going to use this. But something is clear for me it's the complexity that is going to bring.

An other alternative is to start two nova-compute services on a same host with for each a specific vcpu_pin_set.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-02-24 08:45:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12.'}, {'account_id': 25625, 'date': '2018-02-24 08:50:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-02-13 06:24:08.000000000', 'message': "Add hw:cpu_policy 'mixed' for better CPU utilization

This feature will allow libvirt driver to pin guest vCPUs to
host pCPUs and at the same time allows guest vCPUS to freely
float across host pCPUs by introducing a new cpu_policy `mixed`
thereby achieving better utilization of compute CPU resources.

Implements: bp add-cpu-policy-mixed
Change-Id: I37b05e1025d29d1e79b18a889fa629200f43edfe
"}, {'created': '2018-02-19 01:34:33.000000000', 'message': 'Support shared and dedicated VMs in one host

This feature enables VMs with "cpu-policy=shared" and
"cpu-policy=dedicated" to co-locate on the same host at the same time
by introducing ``vcpu_dedicate_set`` in the nova configuration.

Co-Authored-By: Tetsuro Nakamura <nakamura.tetsuro@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Blueprint: mixed-cpu-policy-host
Change-Id: I37b05e1025d29d1e79b18a889fa629200f43edfe
'}, {'created': '2018-02-19 12:23:14.000000000', 'message': 'Support shared and dedicated VMs in one host

commit_message:
Support shared and dedicated VMs in one host

This feature enables VMs with "cpu-policy=shared" and
"cpu-policy=dedicated" to colocate on the same host at the same time
by introducing ``vcpu_dedicated_set`` in the nova configuration.

Co-Authored-By: Tetsuro Nakamura <nakamura.tetsuro@lab.ntt.co.jp>
Blueprint: mixed-cpu-policy-host
Change-Id: I37b05e1025d29d1e79b18a889fa629200f43edfe

commit_message:
Fix doc build in test script

There is some additional setup required for the docs to be built.
We need to have an implementation so there is something to add to
the api docs, and openstackdocstheme requires a git commit so it
can get the last modified timestamp. Also, we no longer generate a
Changelog since we aren't using pbr now so we need to remove that
or we have a missing file.

Change-Id: Ic79aa0fb8f7e5813bec420c8b2690b0e9ef79cc2

commit_message:
Add test script to verify tox targets run

We should be verifying that the tox target defined will run after
generating a project. There's no reason a brand new cookiecutter
repo should have failing tests.

Change-Id: Id142abd2f510a8cbfb42d32fb3f169a63552b981

commit_message:
Fix stestr configuration

.stestr.conf was missing, and in the lower-constraints tests we
weren't getting stestr installed, probably because we were using an
older version of oslotest that didn't depend on it. We should have
an explicit dep on it anyway so it is added to test-requirements.

Some old testr cruft is also cleaned up.

Change-Id: Ia754ee7bc01f87c96ca3e979ec0d6a54001f4bc7

This is the preferred method for building api docs now.

for all of the Tested Runtimes for Train.

https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/train/python3-updates.html

messages:
[{'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-02-28 17:01:52.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-02-28 17:53:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think the squash option is intended for cases where you rarely have shared history between layers, e.g. when images are built individually in a CI/CD pipeline. If they have shared history there is less benefit to squashing.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-02-28 17:55:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I think the squash option is intended for cases where you rarely
 > have shared history between layers, e.g. when images are built
 > individually in a CI/CD pipeline. If they have shared history there
 > is less benefit to squashing.

Actually, looks like this might also produce squashed 'base' images (base, openstack-base, nova-base) etc, with a single layer per Dockerfile. Have I got that right? If so it should be useful. We still might want to allow both types of squashing - a full squash might be more efficient if there is no shared history between images."}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-02-28 18:10:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> this might also produce squashed 'base' images (base, openstack-base, nova-base) etc, with a single layer per Dockerfile.

Exactly, that was one of the goals. Unfortunately, top-level layer misses link to parent after squashing, so `docker history` gives you the following

$ docker history kolla/ubuntu-binary-keystone-ssh:5.0.5
IMAGE               CREATED             CREATED BY                                      SIZE                COMMENT
aed50e78b9a4        45 minutes ago                                                      7.71MB              
<missing>           About an hour ago                                                   78.2MB              
<missing>           About an hour ago                                                   137MB               
<missing>           About an hour ago                                                   130MB               
<missing>           5 weeks ago         /bin/sh -c #(nop)  CMD ["/bin/bash"]            0B                  
<missing>           5 weeks ago         /bin/sh -c mkdir -p /run/systemd && echo 'do‚Ä¶   7B                  
<missing>           5 weeks ago         /bin/sh -c rm -rf /var/lib/apt/lists/*          0B                  
<missing>           5 weeks ago         /bin/sh -c set -xe   && echo '#!/bin/sh' > /‚Ä¶   745B                
<missing>           5 weeks ago         /bin/sh -c #(nop) ADD file:916a45030dee881bb‚Ä¶   117MB 

5 layers at the bottom are from ubuntu, then goes base, openstack-base, keystone-base, keystone-ssh'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-01 11:12:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-01 11:15:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-02 18:43:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-05 08:56:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-10 10:22:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-10 15:23:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Patch Set 5 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 23942, 'date': '2019-03-10 20:40:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

I thought existing squashing is producing layers per each 'parent'. So for example there would be:
- os layer
- base layer
- openstack-base layer
- component-base layer
- final component layer

Which is exactly as optimised as possible. I need to check though."}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-11 20:40:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 7562, 'date': '2019-03-12 04:59:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-03-12 09:22:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-28 17:01:52.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Change number of squashed levels

Kolla squashes images down to the latest (actually, first)
layer in image's history, and this have the following drawbacks:

* all meaning of having a chain of containers is lost as after
  squashing you have one big image that contains only one layer.

* sometimes this leads to problems when building multiple images
  at once as some layers just disappears because of squashing.

This commit changes this a bit, squashing only layers from top
(newest layer) to the first that have tags. This allows to keep
older layers intact, and effectively reduce size of container
being built.

Change-Id: Id65d7832298e537c82df214db8fd0d1ae4f81d20
"}, {'created': '2019-03-01 11:12:58.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Improve image squashing

Kolla squashes images staring from the first layer (oldest image in history),
and this have the following drawbacks:

* all meaning of having a chain of containers is lost as after
  squashing you have one big image that contains only one layer.

* this leads to failures when building multiple images at once because
  docker-squash tryies to remove layers after squashing, but some
  layers were used when building 'child' images, so docker-squash reports
  an error.

This commit changes this a bit, allowing to specify an image where to
start squashing. For this a new option '--squash-from' was added. It has
a format of '<key>:<value>' string. <key> could be either 'tag' or
'tag-index':

If 'tag':

  Use '--squash-from tag:<image tag>' to tell docker-squash
  that image should be squashed starting at layer tagged with <image tag>

If 'tag-index':

  Use '--squash-from tag-index:<N>' to tell docker-squash
  that image should be squashed from Nth taggerd layer in image's history.
  Intermediate layers that are not tagged are ignored.
  Index '0' refers to current image (newest), index '-1' is oldest one
  (usually this is OS image). Most useful case is to have index '1',
  that means 'squash starting from previous tagged image'.

Change-Id: Id65d7832298e537c82df214db8fd0d1ae4f81d20

"}, {'created': '2019-03-10 10:22:19.000000000', 'message': "Improve image squashing

Kolla squashes images staring from the first layer (oldest image in history),
and this have the following drawbacks:

* after squashing you have one big image that contains only one layer,
  so it's not possible to have a chain of layers to use several relatively
  big images as common ancestors to multiple small (final) layers.

* this leads to failures when building multiple images at once because
  docker-squash tryies to remove layers after squashing, but some
  layers were used when building 'child' images, so docker-squash reports
  an error.

This commit changes this a bit, allowing to specify an image where to
start squashing. For this a new option '--squash-from' was added. It has
a format of '<key>:<value>' string. <key> could be either 'tag' or
'tag-index':

If 'tag':

  Use '--squash-from tag:<image tag>' to tell docker-squash
  that image should be squashed starting at layer tagged with <image tag>

If 'tag-index':

  Use '--squash-from tag-index:<N>' to tell docker-squash
  that image should be squashed from Nth taggerd layer in image's history.
  Intermediate layers that are not tagged are ignored. Index could be
  used the same way as for python lists:
    0 - index of an oldest layer (at the bottom of 'docker history' output)
    1 - index of the first tagged image (counting from bottom), usualli this
        is an operating system image
    -1 - index of the last tagged image
  The most typical usage should be '--squash-from tag-index:-1' to squash
  all layers produced during the build of the current container.

Change-Id: Id65d7832298e537c82df214db8fd0d1ae4f81d20

commit_message:
Fix image squashing

Kolla squashes images staring from the first (oldest in the history) layer,
and this have the following drawbacks:

* after squashing you have one big image that contains only one layer,
  so it's not possible to have a chain of layers to use several relatively
  big images as common ancestors to multiple small (final) layers.

* this leads to failures when building multiple images at once because
  docker-squash tryies to remove layers after squashing, but some
  layers were used when building 'child' images, so docker-squash reports
  an error.

This commit fixes this by selecting previous tagged image as 'starting point'.
If there is no such images for some reason then squashing skipped with
warning message.

It also adds 'docker-squash' to requirements.txt.

Change-Id: Id65d7832298e537c82df214db8fd0d1ae4f81d20

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-22 08:24:54.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
(cherry picked from commit 19f9b37721d9bc13bc1ed35a4f368b1d21b10a5b)
(cherry picked from commit 7ee6bf867359b2ff06c0e41b0aec1f80b588ddf3)
'}]
commit_message:
Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
(cherry picked from commit 19f9b37721d9bc13bc1ed35a4f368b1d21b10a5b)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-22 08:24:10.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
(cherry picked from commit 19f9b37721d9bc13bc1ed35a4f368b1d21b10a5b)
'}]
commit_message:
Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
(cherry picked from commit 19f9b37721d9bc13bc1ed35a4f368b1d21b10a5b)

commit_message:
Don't create symlink for swift container logs

logrotate 3.14.0 silently ignores all files when
there is a broken symlink in the container.

Change-Id: I52a74c7b5473340e2afd240d7d6af9ad5bc97544
Closes-Bug: #1833690
(cherry picked from commit d3a9614d8a631c1d29683d6426f501b88ecc2f85)

commit_message:
Add new vif_details parameters

Added two new vif_details parameters:
  - connectivity: informs about the back-end connectivity level (l2,
    l3 or not specified).
  - bound_drivers: a dict of binding level to driver name.

Change-Id: I7786516672af795ac7f192504102a7388c6b7d80
Related-Bug: #1821058

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-24 09:17:03.000000000', 'message': "dpdk: misc fixes for EAL initialization

For OpenStack Queens and later instances are setup with vhostuser
ports in server mode, with the OVS side of the port connecting
as a client to the vhostuser socket on disk; as a result we no
longer need to pass permissions information via dpdk-extra (the
two passed options are not valid in later OVS versions).

In addition, we should also whitelist the devices we're going to
use; this ensures that EAL initialization does not take an extended
period of time reducing the amount of time taken to restart OVS.

Change-Id: I224e778de0ed6e279b2de7f4f46781df33121165
Closes-Bug: 1833734
Closes-Bug: 1793729
"}]
commit_message:
dpdk: misc fixes for EAL initialization

For OpenStack Queens and later instances are setup with vhostuser
ports in server mode, with the OVS side of the port connecting
as a client to the vhostuser socket on disk; as a result we no
longer need to pass permissions information via dpdk-extra (the
two passed options are not valid in later OVS versions).

In addition, we should also whitelist the devices we're going to
use; this ensures that EAL initialization does not take an extended
period of time reducing the amount of time taken to restart OVS.

Change-Id: I224e778de0ed6e279b2de7f4f46781df33121165
Closes-Bug: 1833734

commit_message:
Set the tripleo-ansible project to use storyboard

As an action item from our more recent meeting, the tripleo-ansible
project will use storyboard to track work items. This change should
enable us to use storyboard.

Meeting minutes:
http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/tripleo/2019/tripleo.2019-06-20-13.01.html

Change-Id: Idbfdeb74baa9053073bb9c430285fd884217fc7b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Mention [cinder]/cross_az_attach in the AZ docs

Since the [cinder]/cross_az_attach configuration is all
about availability zones matching between servers and volumes,
we should mention it in the AZ documentation.

Change-Id: I7055104d0b9dbd7efdef6d02c18541172059724f

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-23 21:11:31.000000000', 'message': "WIP: Optimize hypervisor API calls

The nova CDM builder code and notification handling
code had some inefficiencies when it came to looking
up a hypevisor to get details. The general pattern
used before was:

1. get the minimal hypervisor information by hypervisor_hostname
2. make another query to get the hypervisor details by id

In the notifications case, it was actually three calls because
the first is listing hyprvisors to filter client-side by service
host.

This change collapses 1 and 2 above into a single API call
to get the hypervisor by hypervisor_hostname with details
which will include the service (compute) host information
which is what get_compute_node_by_id() was being used for.
Now that nothing is using get_compute_node_by_id it is removed.

There is more work we could do in get_compute_node_by_hostname
if the compute API allowed filtering hypervisors by service
host so a TODO is left for that.

One final thing: the TODO in get_compute_node_by_hostname about
there being more than one hypervisor per compute service host
for vmware vcenter is not accurate - nova's vcenter driver
hasn't supported a host:node 1:M topology like that since the
Liberty release [1]. The only in-tree driver in nova that supports
1:M is the ironic baremetal driver, so the comment is updated.

[1] Ifc17c5049e3ed29c8dd130339207907b00433960

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/659886/
Change-Id: I5e0e88d7b2dd1a69117ab03e0e66851c687606da

commit_message:
Optimize hypervisor API calls

The nova CDM builder code and notification handling
code had some inefficiencies when it came to looking
up a hypevisor to get details. The general pattern
used before was:

1. get the minimal hypervisor information by hypervisor_hostname
2. make another query to get the hypervisor details by id

In the notifications case, it was actually three calls because
the first is listing hyprvisors to filter client-side by service
host.

This change collapses 1 and 2 above into a single API call
to get the hypervisor by hypervisor_hostname with details
which will include the service (compute) host information
which is what get_compute_node_by_id() was being used for.
Now that nothing is using get_compute_node_by_id it is removed.

There is more work we could do in get_compute_node_by_hostname
if the compute API allowed filtering hypervisors by service
host so a TODO is left for that.

One final thing: the TODO in get_compute_node_by_hostname about
there being more than one hypervisor per compute service host
for vmware vcenter is not accurate - nova's vcenter driver
hasn't supported a host:node 1:M topology like that since the
Liberty release [1]. The only in-tree driver in nova that supports
1:M is the ironic baremetal driver, so the comment is updated.

[1] Ifc17c5049e3ed29c8dd130339207907b00433960

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/661785/
Change-Id: I5e0e88d7b2dd1a69117ab03e0e66851c687606da

commit_message:
add libvirt image metadata traits

- This change introduces standard traits for the
  well defined hw_disk_model, hw_cdrom_model, hw_video_model
  and hw_vif_model image metadata properties.
- This spec defines all of the new traits in the compute
  namespace as they represent the ability of a hypervisor to
  emulate a specific virtual device model, not the presence
  of the respective hardware device on the host.

Change-Id: I42237b196644bfa87701f978a1519941d447b450
Task: 30526
Story: 2005447

commit_message:
Replace merge_configs with merge_yaml for merge mongodb.conf

Actually, 'mongodb.conf' is a yaml format configuration file. Do not use
merge_configs to merge it.

Change-Id: Id3c006df00c1e2d66472c2195781e01c640cab22
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-03 16:39:19.000000000', 'message': 'Method for Kolla-ansible to override the default ceilometer meters.yaml

Similar to what we did here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655276/
but, for ceilometer/data/meters.d/meters.yaml file.

The idea is to create a method for operators to manage custom meters YAML files via Kolla-ansible. To do that, we enable them (operators) to use a folder called by default "meters.d" in their local ceilometer configurations, where all of the custom meters YAML files will be read from. If this folder exist and has YAML files in it, we copy them for the default "/etc/ceilometer/meters.d" path in the containers. We do not inject things in the container though. We copy the files for the control node, and then we map them via ceilometer*.json container configuration files.

Change-Id: I712edcf39bfdb64887e25437f0aff30a45a829dd

commit_message:
Method to override the default ceilometer meters.yaml via Kolla-ansible

Similar to what we did here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655276 but,
 for ceilometer/data/meters.d/meters.yaml file.

The idea is to create a method for operators to manage custom meters
 YAML files via Kolla-ansible. To do that, we enable them (operators)
 to use a folder called by default "meters.d" in their local
 ceilometer configurations, where all of the custom meters YAML files
 will be read from. If this folder exist and has YAML files in it, we
 copy them for the default "/etc/ceilometer/meters.d" path in the
 containers. We do not inject things in the container though. We copy
 the files for the control node, and then we map them via
 ceilometer*.json container configuration files.

Change-Id: I712edcf39bfdb64887e25437f0aff30a45a829dd
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weing√§rtner <rafael@apache.org>

subject: Use 'openstack_service_workers' as the nb of Cloudkitty workers
messages:
[{'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 15:32:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-05-16 15:38:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I'm -1 on this because in kolla we don't try to provide a variable for every possible config option for every service - it would be a maintenance nightmare.

Instead, we provide a configuration override mechanism through which you can set any option.

An exception to this is where we can reuse a variable. We have the openstack_service_workers variable, should we be using it to set the workers for cloudkitty?"}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 15:45:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I'm -1 on this because in kolla we don't try to provide a variable
 > for every possible config option for every service - it would be a
 > maintenance nightmare.
 > 
 > Instead, we provide a configuration override mechanism through
 > which you can set any option.
 > 
 > An exception to this is where we can reuse a variable. We have the
 > openstack_service_workers variable, should we be using it to set
 > the workers for cloudkitty?

Hmm. I was not aware of this other variable. I guess we can re-use it. What do you think? I can apply the changes to use 'openstack_service_workers' instead.

I do know the override method, but I personally do not like it. For instance, here, just to change a single parameter, I would need to copy and paste the whole file, and append my "extra config", which will make me version this file from now on, and to handle conflicts with updates in Kolla-ansible templates.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-05-16 16:55:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > I'm -1 on this because in kolla we don't try to provide a
 > variable
 > > for every possible config option for every service - it would be
 > a
 > > maintenance nightmare.
 > >
 > > Instead, we provide a configuration override mechanism through
 > > which you can set any option.
 > >
 > > An exception to this is where we can reuse a variable. We have
 > the
 > > openstack_service_workers variable, should we be using it to set
 > > the workers for cloudkitty?
 > 
 > Hmm. I was not aware of this other variable. I guess we can re-use
 > it. What do you think? I can apply the changes to use
 > 'openstack_service_workers' instead.

It makes sense to me.

 > 
 > I do know the override method, but I personally do not like it. For
 > instance, here, just to change a single parameter, I would need to
 > copy and paste the whole file, and append my "extra config", which
 > will make me version this file from now on, and to handle conflicts
 > with updates in Kolla-ansible templates.

Your custom configuration files are merged with those in kolla-ansible using the merge_configs action plugin. This means you only need to set the additional configs you need.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 18:23:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 18:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > > I'm -1 on this because in kolla we don't try to provide a
 > > variable
 > > > for every possible config option for every service - it would
 > be
 > > a
 > > > maintenance nightmare.
 > > >
 > > > Instead, we provide a configuration override mechanism through
 > > > which you can set any option.
 > > >
 > > > An exception to this is where we can reuse a variable. We have
 > > the
 > > > openstack_service_workers variable, should we be using it to
 > set
 > > > the workers for cloudkitty?
 > >
 > > Hmm. I was not aware of this other variable. I guess we can
 > re-use
 > > it. What do you think? I can apply the changes to use
 > > 'openstack_service_workers' instead.
 > 
 > It makes sense to me.

Done. I have to really thank you for the feedback you are providing in my PRs, they have been very valuable.

 > 
 > >
 > > I do know the override method, but I personally do not like it.
 > For
 > > instance, here, just to change a single parameter, I would need
 > to
 > > copy and paste the whole file, and append my "extra config",
 > which
 > > will make me version this file from now on, and to handle
 > conflicts
 > > with updates in Kolla-ansible templates.
 > 
 > Your custom configuration files are merged with those in
 > kolla-ansible using the merge_configs action plugin. This means you
 > only need to set the additional configs you need.

Hmm, so we have not been using the override mechanism as we should. We are always copying the whole file and appending the configs we want, and that is why I disliked it so much.

So, by your explanation, if I have a template for a python configuration file that has a section called "[sectionX]", and in this template, we just have one variable declared in that section, such as:
[sectionX]
variable1 = "value"

Then, if I want to "add a second variable there", I could just create an "override file" with the following content:
[sectionX]
variable2 = "value"

Then, when these templates are processed, they will generate:
[sectionX]
variable1 = "value"
variable2 = "value"

Is that it?'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 18:30:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-16 18:30:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-05-17 15:31:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-17 15:53:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-17 15:53:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> (1 comment)

Ok, fixed.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-05-17 17:23:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

 > Is there a reason not to just use the default for that?

I am not sure about the 'max_greenthreads', but in our case, regarding the 'max_workers,' there is a reason.

Depending on the number of tenants, the first time it is processing, it can take quite a while. Therefore, we needed to increase the max_workes value because the default one is quite low.

Also, afterwards, we wanted to fine-tune the number of workers, because they can lead to performance degradation in the MySQL DB.'}, {'account_id': 23060, 'date': '2019-05-22 07:53:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Let's keep it like this for now, I don't see why somebody would want to use something else than the default for max_greenthreads"}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:53:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Use 'openstack_service_workers' as the nb of Cloudkitty workers

Add the ability to Kolla-ansible to manage the 'max_workers' parameter
 in Cloudkitty. We will use the 'openstack_service_workers' variable
 to control the number of workers that Cloudkitty is able to use.

Change-Id: I2f4e7e5c45d71a7e01d1b743d2eb4850cc339419
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weing√§rtner <rafael@apache.org>

commit_message:
Remove ``hnas_iscsi`` from the supported storage backends list of Cinder

The Hitachi NAS Platform iSCSI driver was marked as not supported by
Cinder in the Ocata realease[1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/444287/

Change-Id: I1a25789374fddaefc57bc59badec06f91ee6a52a
Closes-Bug: #1832821

commit_message:
Avoid parallel discover_hosts (nova-related race condition)

In a rare event both kolla-ansible and nova-scheduler try to do
the mapping at the same time and one of them fails.
Since kolla-ansible runs host discovery on each deployment,
there is no need to change the default of no periodic host discovery.

I added some notes for future. They are not critical.
I made the decision explicit in the comments.
I changed the task name to satisfy recommendations.
I removed the variable because it is not used (to avoid future doubts).

Closes-Bug: #1832987

Change-Id: I3128472f028a2dbd7ace02abc179a9629ad74ceb
Signed-off-by: Rados≈Çaw Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add some notes for users Migrating to Kolla Monasca

This commit should help guide people migrating to Kolla Monasca
through the murky depths of the migration process. Since Kolla
did not support Monasca in Queens, some of these steps which
could be automated are not.

Change-Id: I79051cca27178c3cf1671f5c603e38baf929c55c

subject: Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-18 18:09:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:16:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 22629, 'date': '2019-06-19 20:35:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 24072, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:40:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 18:09:14.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)

commit_message:
Add unit test for keystone fernet cron generator

Before making changes to this script, document its behaviour with a unit
test.

There are two major issues:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day results in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, results in no jobs

Change-Id: I655da1102dfb4ca12437b7db0b79c9a61568f79e
Related-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 25ac955a4e2645da29f8c7b807f0bac5afb43838)

should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone fernet key rotation scheduling

Right now every controller rotates fernet keys. This is nice because
should any controller die, we know the remaining ones will rotate the
keys. However, we are currently over-rotating the keys.

When we over rotate keys, we get logs like this:

 This is not a recognized Fernet token <token> TokenNotFound

Most clients can recover and get a new token, but some clients (like
Nova passing tokens to other services) can't do that because it doesn't
have the password to regenerate a new token.

With three controllers, in crontab in keystone-fernet we see the once a day
correctly staggered across the three controllers:

ssh ctrl1 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 0 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl2 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 8 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh
ssh ctrl3 sudo cat /etc/kolla/keystone-fernet/crontab
0 16 * * * /usr/bin/fernet-rotate.sh

Currently with three controllers we have this keystone config:

[token]
expiration = 86400 (although, keystone default is one hour)
allow_expired_window = 172800 (this is the keystone default)

[fernet_tokens]
max_active_keys = 4

Currently, kolla-ansible configures key rotation according to the following:

   rotation_interval = token_expiration / num_hosts

This means we rotate keys more quickly the more hosts we have, which doesn't
make much sense.

Keystone docs state:

   max_active_keys =
     ((token_expiration + allow_expired_window) / rotation_interval) + 2

For details see:
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/stein/admin/fernet-token-faq.html

Rotation is based on pushing out a staging key, so should any server
start using that key, other servers will consider that valid. Then each
server in turn starts using the staging key, each in term demoting the
existing primary key to a secondary key. Eventually you prune the
secondary keys when there is no token in the wild that would need to be
decrypted using that key. So this all makes sense.

This change adds new variables for fernet_token_allow_expired_window and
fernet_key_rotation_interval, so that we can correctly calculate the
correct number of active keys. We now set the default rotation interval
so as to minimise the number of active keys to 3 - one primary, one
secondary, one buffer.

This change also fixes the fernet cron job generator, which was broken
in the following cases:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day resulted in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, resulted in no jobs

It should now be possible to request any interval up to a week divided
by the number of hosts.

Change-Id: I10c82dc5f83653beb60ddb86d558c5602153341a
Closes-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 6c1442c385450004dd253f3f464fe4336194be99)

commit_message:
Add unit test for keystone fernet cron generator

Before making changes to this script, document its behaviour with a unit
test.

There are two major issues:

* requesting an interval of more than 1 day results in no jobs
* requesting an interval of more than 60 minutes, unless an exact
  multiple of 60 minutes, results in no jobs

Change-Id: I655da1102dfb4ca12437b7db0b79c9a61568f79e
Related-Bug: #1809469
(cherry picked from commit 25ac955a4e2645da29f8c7b807f0bac5afb43838)

subject: Adds support for choosing first network created in context.
messages:
[{'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-05-31 14:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2019-05-31 14:03:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-03 08:59:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-03 13:42:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-03 13:42:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 9545, 'date': '2019-06-14 15:59:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 21528, 'date': '2019-06-17 11:51:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Could we pass the default value of auto_assign_nic with True ?'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:49:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Could we pass the default value of auto_assign_nic with True ?

If you pass parameter 'auto_assign_nic' with 'True' value, it will work. But most of scenarios doesn't accept this parameter..."}, {'account_id': 21528, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:21:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Sorry, I still can not understand what you meant.
'auto_assign_nic' could not be passed by scenarios if the default value is True, it would randomly pick one network while there is not nics specified."}, {'account_id': 21528, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:25:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Did you mean some scenarios passed 'auto_assign_nic' False inside scenarios ?"}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:30:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Sorry, I still can not understand what you meant.
 > 'auto_assign_nic' could not be passed by scenarios if the default
 > value is True, it would randomly pick one network while there is
 > not nics specified.

Well if you didn't set parameter 'auto_assign_nic' on 'True' (e.g. because scenario doesn't accept this parameter) and also you didn't specify nics (net-id) - (e.g. because you want to use network created in context), it will fail with error 'novaclient.exceptions.Conflict: Multiple possible networks found, use a Network ID to be more specific. (HTTP 409)'."}, {'account_id': 21528, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:51:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

In your case, looks we just need to fix line 52 to `auto_assign_nic=True`, or fix line 74 to `if not kwargs.get("nics", False):`.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-19 11:28:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

> In your case, looks we just need to fix line 52 to
 > `auto_assign_nic=True`, or fix line 74 to `if not kwargs.get("nics",
 > False):`.

Yes remove 'auto_assign_nic' parameter completely would be solution as well. I mean leave it just like that:

if not kwargs.get("nics", False):
    nic = self._pick_random_nic()
    if nic:
        kwargs["nics"] = nic

Set default value to 'True' has the same effect as removing it completely.'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-19 14:07:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 29738, 'date': '2019-06-24 09:29:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

recheck'}]

commit_message:
Adds support for choosing first network created in context.

If scenario doesn't accept parameter 'auto_assign_nic'
it will choose first available network created in context.

Change-Id: I3aa8bb2d400abb593f5a2110b5aab82e3d08fcdb
Closes-Bug: #1831247
