revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-19 03:39:58.000000000', 'message': 'Use UTF-8 to decode subprocess output on py3

Otherwise, you get output like

    Branch: master
    Source: src/opendev.org/openstack/swift
    Requirements: /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements
    git log -n 1 --format=%H
    Patch under test: b'f683ca84318da31492f214f978a55bdc1be70c2c'
    git --git-dir /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements/.git rev-parse HEAD
    requirements git sha: b'9ebc858033d7998a167941f1b7b060de60d17244'
    virtualenv /tmp/tmp9l32_z5b/venv
    /tmp/tmp9l32_z5b/venv/bin/pip install /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements
    Checking b'f683ca84318da31492f214f978a55bdc1be70c2c'

(Note the bytes getting interpolated in the "Patch under test",
"requirements git sha", and "Checking" lines.)

Change-Id: I836a6218ff5fccf4aab74b37a5a682601a388106
'}]
commit_message:
Use UTF-8 to decode subprocess output on py3

Otherwise, you get output like

    Branch: master
    Source: src/opendev.org/openstack/swift
    Requirements: /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements
    git log -n 1 --format=%H
    Patch under test: b'f683ca84318da31492f214f978a55bdc1be70c2c'
    git --git-dir /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements/.git rev-parse HEAD
    requirements git sha: b'9ebc858033d7998a167941f1b7b060de60d17244'
    virtualenv /tmp/tmp9l32_z5b/venv
    /tmp/tmp9l32_z5b/venv/bin/pip install /home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements
    Checking b'f683ca84318da31492f214f978a55bdc1be70c2c'

(Note the bytes getting interpolated in the "Patch under test",
"requirements git sha", and "Checking" lines.)

Change-Id: I836a6218ff5fccf4aab74b37a5a682601a388106

commit_message:
Make Ceph upgrade check Ceph release to avoid EPERM

Since we have different upgrade paths, we must use the actually
installed Ceph release name when doing require-osd-release

Closes-Bug: #1832989

Change-Id: I6aaa4b4ac0fb739f7ad885c13f55b6db969996a2
Signed-off-by: Rados≈Çaw Piliszek <radoslaw.piliszek@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 0ea991e4d2c633ec97c1c9e9b7c96ee3b053a446)

commit_message:
Add missed 'Server ID' output in attachment-list

'server_id' is not Attachment attribute, should be
set by 'instance' attribute.

v3/attachments respond body:

{"attachments":
   [{"status": "attached",
     "instance": INSTANCE_UUID,
     "id": ATTACHMENT_UUID,
     "volume_id": VOLUME_UUID,
    },
    ...
    ]
}

Change-Id: Ica5d278cb7455befe1db4be0ab65114fd606ea0a

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 04:29:47.000000000', 'message': "DVR: on new port only send router update on port's host

When new DVR serviceable port appears on new node we need
to update node's l3 agent with all routers which have the
port's subnets, including connected routers.
We don't need to update all nodes hosting these routers.
It costs us much as all l3 agents then go back to neutron server
and request routers info for no good reason.
This was one of the main issues with DVR at scale fixed in Mitaka.

Change-Id: I99d01d7bf29f236eff0f80d1ae8659f64ac55d39
Related-Bug: #1830456
(cherry picked from commit 52529bc949acff9a3454abd44925342468064b78)
"}]
commit_message:
DVR: on new port only send router update on port's host

When new DVR serviceable port appears on new node we need
to update node's l3 agent with all routers which have the
port's subnets, including connected routers.
We don't need to update all nodes hosting these routers.
It costs us much as all l3 agents then go back to neutron server
and request routers info for no good reason.
This was one of the main issues with DVR at scale fixed in Mitaka.

Change-Id: I99d01d7bf29f236eff0f80d1ae8659f64ac55d39
Related-Bug: #1830456
(cherry picked from commit 52529bc949acff9a3454abd44925342468064b78)

commit_message:
Implement Apache WSGI for Qinling

Since this review[1], Qinling supports WSGI execution.

From a production perspective, Qinling should be deployed
using Apache and mod_wsgi.

"api_worker" option is not needed anymore because processes will
be handle by Apache mod_wsgi.

Qinling Docker image review[2] has ben created.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/661851
[2] https://review.opendev.org/666647

Change-Id: I9aaee4c2932f1e4ea9fe780a64e96a28fa6bccfb
Story: 2005920
Task: 34181

commit_message:
Re-enable manila dashboard

The Shared File Systems service (manila) provides
a dashboard plugin that needs to be enabled by
tripleo. It appears that it was disabled inadvertently
while triaging a bug with the dashboard and sqlite.

See: Launchpad bug #1766184
and associated commit: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/613186/

Change-Id: If4bc4ed0e9fa31e11a5a701dc57ffdf67aade861
Closes-Bug: #1832302

commit_message:
Switch python3 versions of test jobs to match Train PTI

In Train, we will use python 3.6 and 3.7 for python3 runtime
in our gate jobs [1]. This commit also adds python 3.7.

[1] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Idcedcf7f1629d7b462692270d4345e52e23d3e32

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/651554/8 : SUCCESS in 2h 27m 24s'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-18 17:32:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

FWIW, I *hate* this rule and do not like having to def a thing when a lambda is perfect. Any chance we could just exclude this rule?'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-18 20:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I have to say I agree with Dan that this rule seems silly, especially in test code.

I'm pretty ambivalent between "conform to the rule" and "it's a stupid rule"; so I'll keep my +2 and let someone else break the tie.

But you may want to consider reordering the series :)'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-19 10:40:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> FWIW, I *hate* this rule and do not like having to def a thing when
 > a lambda is perfect. Any chance we could just exclude this rule?

We could, and I do see advantages to doing some shorter things with lambdas. With that said though, writing:

   foo = lambda x: x*2

Doesn't seem all that much shorter or more concise than:

   def foo(x):
       return x*2

Also, for those less-versed in Python, it's probably less clear. There's also the larger changes to 'nova/compute/api.py' and 'nova/tests/unit/db/test_db_api.py' that I would like to keep in any case since I think those make things a good deal clearer.

So idk, I'd like to keep it but I don't want a fight over it"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-19 21:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> for those less-versed in Python

Not to belabor, but this is a hot button for me. "Don't make them learn the language" is the worst possible reason for $anything.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-20 13:56:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> We could, and I do see advantages to doing some shorter things with
 > lambdas. With that said though, writing:
 > 
 > foo = lambda x: x*2
 > 
 > Doesn't seem all that much shorter or more concise than:
 > 
 > def foo(x):
 > return x*2

But pep8 requires you have a certain amount of whitespace before and after the def, which is also stupid. It makes the overall parent function flow significantly uglier.

 > So idk, I'd like to keep it but I don't want a fight over it

If we're going to merge this, I want my -1 to be on it.

--Dan"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-21 17:54:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-06-21 18:15:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-2

This is pointless code churn for a stupid rule, IMHO. I said previously that I wanted my -1 on this if it was going to merge. Since this is now at the end of the series, I'm going to -2 it so it survives rebases. If I'm the only one that thinks this is crazy, then I'll drop to a -1 before merge time."}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-06-21 21:26:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Nova Hyper-V CI

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/651554/9 : FAILURE in 3h 26m 45s'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-06-21 21:59:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-33029 : FAILURE in 3h 36m 09s'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:24:25.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
hacking: Resolve E731 (do not assign a lambda expression, use a def)

Most of these were introduced in
I1ef4a23aa2bf5cb46b481045f3d968f62f74606d though I don't know how they
weren't picked up before. Fix them now anyway.

Change-Id: I6d4c02025cf84572f2f62ac63dd706db9394849e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

subject: Create volume with Chinese character raise error in debug mode
messages:
[{'account_id': 27567, 'date': '2018-01-19 10:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2018-01-19 10:31:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
    Workflow: http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
    Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 27567, 'date': '2018-01-19 13:56:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-01-21 21:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-2

We should not be globally resetting the system encoding as a side-effect of importing the library.

If we need to encode data before it is logged, that should happen in the formatter at the point where the logging occurs.'}, {'account_id': 27567, 'date': '2018-01-26 04:45:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 27567, 'date': '2018-01-26 04:48:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27567, 'date': '2018-01-26 04:53:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

> We should not be globally resetting the system encoding as a
 > side-effect of importing the library.
 > 
 > If we need to encode data before it is logged, that should happen
 > in the formatter at the point where the logging occurs.

Yes, you are right, I have amended as your mind.
Please review it, thanks very much.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:02:44.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

Create volume with Chinese character raise error in debug mode

When set debug True in cinder.conf, Create a volume with Chinese
character will raise error

(14 comments)

Making policy pluggable is going to be *much* more complicated than it was for config. We expose a ton of the internal implementation details of the enforcer, and shoving those behind a wrapper and providing an API that drivers can implement is going to be a lot of work. I've highlighted a few examples of the questions and issues with the current approach, and I think we're going to need to study how this library is really being used before we can settle on an approach that's going to work long term."}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-10 11:23:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-10 12:09:41.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-10 13:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-10 14:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 19.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-10 16:33:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 20.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-10 18:18:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-10 18:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)

It looks like a lot of my comments from the earlier versions still apply to this one.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-11 04:58:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-11 05:12:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 22.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-11 05:15:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 23.'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-11 07:04:51.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 24.'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-11 13:46:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 20:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2018-10-11 20:28:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 24:

Thinking about this some more, I wonder if what we need to do is provide a test fixture that uses the current in-memory evaluation logic and lets callers set the rules then provides an object that matches the current Enforcer API. Then we could clean up some of the API of the Enforcer class to make it possible to define a minimal driver API that didn't have to worry about the project trying to set the enforcement rules or do other things that the tests do. That migration is going to be a lot more work, but I just don't see how we take the current Enforcer API and build a usable driver interface for it. :-/"}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-10-19 06:37:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 24:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10873, 'date': '2018-11-19 13:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 25: Patch Set 24 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-06-24 10:00:39.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

It feels like the effort has stalled. I'm not sure if anyone wants to resuscitate it, and if they do then I'd be happy to help, but for now I'm going to abandon the lot of these to clean up the review queue"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-25 12:53:02.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* An `enforcer` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.enforcer`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a function which returns the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything.

* The primary implementation is the default enforcer returned by our
  driver mechanism.

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7
"}, {'created': '2018-06-25 13:40:40.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.enforcer`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a function which returns the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything.

* The primary implementation is the default enforcer returned by our
  driver mechanism.

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7

"}, {'created': '2018-06-26 13:03:15.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* An `enforcer` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.enforcer`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a meta-class contains the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything and it also allows for
  inheritance (which projects like Glance do).

* The primary implementation is the default enforcer returned by our
  driver mechanism.

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7

"}, {'created': '2018-06-27 09:09:55.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* An `enforcer` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.enforcer`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a meta-class contains the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything and it also allows for
  inheritance (which projects like Glance do).

* In order for classes that inherit from this to be able to use the
  super() call, the Enforcer interface has to define some base functions
  to be exposed. Attributes that are gotten by a regular way
  (self.<attr>) work as expected.

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7
"}, {'created': '2018-06-27 09:10:43.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* An `enforcer` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.enforcer`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a meta-class contains the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything and it also allows for
  inheritance (which projects like Glance do).

* In order for classes that inherit from this to be able to use the
  super() call, the Enforcer interface has to define some base functions
  to be exposed. Attributes that are gotten by a regular way
  (self.<attr>) work as expected. This is because objects returned by
  the super() call, are not the parent objects themselves, but a proxy
  object which implements its own __getattribute__ function.

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7
"}, {'created': '2018-06-28 07:55:07.000000000', 'message': "Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* A `driver` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.drivers`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a meta-class contains the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything and it also allows for
  inheritance (which projects like Glance do).

* In order for classes that inherit from this to be able to use the
  super() call, the Enforcer interface has to define some base functions
  to be exposed. Attributes that are gotten by a regular way
  (self.<attr>) work as expected. This is because objects returned by
  the super() call, are not the parent objects themselves, but a proxy
  object which implements its own __getattribute__ function.

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

bp pluggable-policy-drivers

Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7

commit_message:
Implement base for pluggable policy drivers

This implements the base for pluggable drivers for policy enforcement.
It introduces several things:

* A `driver` configuration option which allows you to specify the
  named entry point from where to load the driver.

* An entry point called `oslo.policy.drivers`, that's used by the
  stevedore driver loader to load the enforcer class.

* The Enforcer class is now a meta-class contains the driver, this
  way the projects don't need to change anything and it also allows for
  inheritance (which projects like Glance do).

* The enforcer plugins will be located in the _enforcers/ directory

bp pluggable-policy-drivers

Depends-On: I9f04f8b8770b15ac24f9f1cd57a58c7e98b24d48
Change-Id: I89990ab33e5b1675f058e8571e9bc8099cd64cf7

commit_message:
POC: Add Open Policy Agent driver

This adds the OPA driver for oslo.policy. Since the agent itself handles
policy, a lot of operations (such as reloading the rules or loding new
rules) are noop's instead.

Change-Id: I3b157764d0f010f139aca2f06d9c5620e5074094

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2015-10-20 12:23:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+1

Build succeeded (check pipeline).

- gate-oslo.policy-pep8 http://logs.openstack.org/21/237521/1/check/gate-oslo.policy-pep8/04c2217/ : SUCCESS in 45s
- gate-oslo.policy-docs http://docs-draft.openstack.org/21/237521/1/check/gate-oslo.policy-docs/079176c//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- gate-oslo.policy-python27 http://logs.openstack.org/21/237521/1/check/gate-oslo.policy-python27/5ecde2c/ : SUCCESS in 55s
- gate-oslo.policy-python34 http://logs.openstack.org/21/237521/1/check/gate-oslo.policy-python34/fea0b6d/ : SUCCESS in 1m 00s
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-oslo.policy http://logs.openstack.org/21/237521/1/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-oslo.policy/5ed3351/ : SUCCESS in 55m 16s'}, {'account_id': 17860, 'date': '2015-10-20 12:45:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I see in the commit message it is a prototype, though I have a few questions about the proposed approach.

i) How are the operations registered into Apache Fortress ? How is the process in the case a service was updated with new operations ?

ii) OpenStack uses RBAC to define access control. In this case, we would be assigning roles to users in Apache Fortress. In that case, are we trying to create an alternative to Keystone service ?

iii) In terms of performance, suppose a cloud with 10k+ users who have access to operation Y. Thus that means every time one try to execute operation X, the whole list of 10k+ users would be retrieved to execute enforcement. Isn't that too bad ?

iv) How would this approach fit with the current authorization mechanism ? Would users get unscoped tokens and then have authorization enforced only by Fortress ?

v) Where do we enforce scope ? For example, we need to check if a domain manager is trying to list users from his domain vs any other domain; rather than just checking he can list users globally.

--

There is an effort to improve the current authorization mechanism in OpenStack. We will have a cross project session at the Tokyo summit to discuss about how our current approach will evolve. See https://mitakadesignsummit.sched.org/event/51c8f2ea29aa0b63f85e424b0acf9741#.ViY2vnW99CU"}, {'account_id': 6482, 'date': '2015-10-20 20:52:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17862, 'date': '2015-10-21 13:23:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Samuel de Medeiros Queiroz: I'm going to shoot video demo of this feature, it will be more clear what this feature is about.
Answers to your questions:
i) We don't care how Apache Fortress is configured, we just read permissions from it, we don'r write anything
ii) We are not replacing keystone, we are replacing policy.json. Some users already have they own RBAC in fortress and they want to use it.
iii) I'm not ready to answer question about performance. Need some research.
iv) Yes, user gets token and then use it as usual. We don't change here anything. What we are changing: oslo_policy Enforcer does not go to policy.json - it  goes to Fortress
v) It depends on Fortress configuration. I didn't work on this case. Need research.

Please, wait for my video demo, I'll post a link. Hope, it'll help to clarify things"}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2015-10-21 16:21:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17862, 'date': '2015-10-27 09:14:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Guys, please take a look https://vimeo.com/143715477'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-24 22:46:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(12 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-02-29 18:15:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

The mitaka release is in feature freeze and only bug fixes for mitaka will be accepted until a stable branch is created. The -2 will be removed when a stable branch is created.'}, {'account_id': 6486, 'date': '2016-03-09 20:02:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

commit_message:
Apache Fortress support prototype

Keystone doesn‚Äôt support full Role-based access control
(RBAC) by itself, but there is a very easy way to fix
that by using a third-party application‚ÄîApache Fortress.
Apache Fortress is an access management system based on
the ANSI RBAC (INCITS 359) standard. It stores rules in
OpenLDAP or Active Directory and has a nice web interface
for viewing and modifying permission.

How it works:
1. Parse action string, split it to object
   and operation
   For example: "identity:list_users" =>
                object:    identity
                operation: list_users
2. List all Fortress users who have
   permissions in Fortress for object and
   operation
3. Check if current user is in list

Code was tested on local deployment.

Change-Id: I0901854caa18d28853b8a6467d916e7fb2165222
Implements: blueprint apache-fortress-support

I'm looking at the patch that originally added sample defaults, and I think this breaks the use case it was trying to address: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/104226/

Basically the goal was to prevent things like actual hostnames from showing up in the sample default when code is being called to generate the default.  Since the hostname of the system generating the sample file and the one on which the file is being deployed is likely different, this change would result in a bogus default still being presented.

Maybe we just need some way to flag when a sample default is being used, so operators can easily see that the "default" presented isn't necessarily what is being used?  I don't have a specific idea in mind as to how that would look, but I wanted to throw it out there for other people to mull over.'}, {'account_id': 14611, 'date': '2016-10-11 21:34:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1

@Ben, I see your point, but I think this change is step toward good direction. Without that, samples were populated as default. Now, default is not set, and it's easily visible, that config needs to be modified."}, {'account_id': 19611, 'date': '2016-10-17 18:25:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

@Ben, the original goal was to present it as stated in the blueprint, but it seems if there is no default, it's better to communicate this.  Of, if there is a default, let the user see the actual default value while showing them what an example value is.

The problem is today, the sample_default overrides the default value, which is a miscommunication as the actual default value is hidden at this point, users need to see what the actual default would be."}, {'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2016-11-21 23:27:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Really, really sorry for the delay getting back to this.  I hate hit-and-run -1's and now I've done it. :-(

 > @Ben, the original goal was to present it as stated in the
 > blueprint, but it seems if there is no default, it's better to
 > communicate this.  Of, if there is a default, let the user see the
 > actual default value while showing them what an example value is.

The problem is that in the intended use case for this parameter, the "actual" default value isn't.  The previously stated hostname case is one of these (well, unless the sample config is always generated on the system where it will be used), and the other I'm personally aware of is cases where None is used as a sentinel value that is later set to the actual default in code.  My personal experience with this was when we deprecated a default value so we could change it in a future release and needed a way to know whether the default or a value that happened to match the default was in use so we could log deprecation warnings.  Previously we could use sample_default to communicate the actual default, whereas this would break that behavior.

I'm curious what use cases exist for sample_default where this results in a valid value being written to the config.  The unit tests are kind of a bad example here because they're overriding one static default with another static value, which seems like nonsense to me.  Is there a real world config opt in some project where this change results in a valid default being written to the sample config file?'}, {'account_id': 9796, 'date': '2017-02-09 15:09:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

commit_message:
Sample Default Handling

Sample default, if provided currently overrides
a default value in sample files if set.  This aims
to change this behavior to list the sample_default
as an example if a default value is provided.  This
will also change how the sample_default is presented
if no default value is provided. Prior behavior with
no default is to place the sample_default in the
default, which causes confusion.  This will ensure
the sample_default is presented as an example, while
still inidicating there is no default.

Change-Id: Idef516db34aeef424b082e02a90daceabbd3d400
Implements: blueprint oslo-generator-sample-default

commit_message:
Add log handler for Sentry

Added new option sentry-dsn that allows Sentry integration
via raven package. The raven log handler is initialized if
the sentry-dsn option is non empty string.
Sentry is an open-source error tracking tool https://sentry.io.

Change-Id: I69e9177f7b92a9f610ff49f917c08f39a4b3f1c0
Implements: blueprint sentry-handler

commit_message:
Switch to use stestr for unit test

According to Openstack summit session [1],
stestr is maintained project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
So we should switch to stestr.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: Ibe4340918dfa0571df521f36c41caa4c479a2c92

'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 22:01:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add gate job for stable/stein

Now we have stable/stein branch ready for devstack
and so does for all service projects.

This commit adds the stable/stein job running for
d-g gate.

NOTE: Adding legacy job vesion of stable/stein because
only legacy jobs use devstack-gate which is what we need
to test.

This commit removes the all stable zuulv3 native jobs
which does not use devstack-gate and so does not required

commit_message:
Add gate job for stable/stein

Now we have stable/stein branch ready for devstack
and so does for all service projects.

This commit adds the stable/stein job running for
d-g gate.

NOTE: Adding legacy job vesion of stable/stein because
only legacy jobs use devstack-gate which is what we need
to test.

This commit removes the all stable zuulv3 native jobs
which does not use devstack-gate and so does not required
to be tested here.

Change-Id: I546038fa4164a3085b33fa0ef30a51ec237bdc3f

[{'created': '2017-12-01 01:19:59.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: support pipfile

This change adds preliminary support for Pipfile in
PBR.
It allows packages using Pipfile instead of
requirements.txt to see their own dependencies found by PBR.
Without it, upon installation of a package using
Pipfile, only it content is installed, not its
dependencies

I had to inject the TOML decoder and pipfile parser
in order to make pbr able to read the Pipfile. Adding
these dependencies in a requirements.txt of PBR is
impossible because they need to be available
before PBR could have installed it.

TODO:
- support -f
- support other than ¬´\xa0git+\xa0¬ª http installation
  method
- support markers
- add more unit tests

Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/+bug/1726561

Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>

commit_message:
WIP: support pipfile

This change adds preliminary support for Pipfile in
PBR.
It allows packages using Pipfile instead of
requirements.txt to see their own dependencies found by PBR.
Without it, upon installation of a package using
Pipfile (through pipenv), only its content is
installed, not its dependencies.

Implementation notes:
I had to inject the TOML decoder and pipfile parser
in order to make pbr able to read the Pipfile. Adding
these dependencies in a requirements.txt of PBR is
impossible because they need to be available
before PBR could have installed it.

Also, I choose to not implement read from lock
file on purpose, I think PBR is operating inside
an application (using pipenv or bare pip) that
may choose or not to freeze dependencies
(through Pipfile.lock on frozen requirements).
But libraries but describe its dependencies
by compatibility range.

TODO:
- support -f syntax for pip install
- support other than ¬´¬†git+¬†¬ª http installation
  methods (never used other)
- support markers (pipfile spec not frozen). Might
  allow compatibility range description
- add more unit tests

Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/pbr/+bug/1726561

Change-Id: I680cace8009e8984224fb315de3b2cd5bbc82d9d
Signed-off-by: Gaetan Semet <gaetan@xeberon.net>

subject: [WIP] prefer to use pymemcache.client.PooledClient instead of redesign client pool
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-02-14 16:35:27.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] prefer to use pymemcache.client.PooledClient instead of redesign client pool

Pymemcache come with a client pool manager and thread safe, these
introduce him and prefer to use it instead of redesign/redefine
completly this kind of mechanism here.

We keep the main class MemcacheClientPool to doesn't break things
on the customer side and to centtralize client pool on oslo cache
instead rise technical debt on the whole openstack by duplicating
these uses.

Change-Id: I2c6355d9e116408d96c53a29175bc0798f775722
"}]
commit_message:
[WIP] prefer to use pymemcache.client.PooledClient instead of redesign client pool

Pymemcache come with a client pool manager and thread safe, these
introduce him and prefer to use it instead of redesign/redefine
completly this kind of mechanism here.

We keep the main class MemcacheClientPool to doesn't break things
on the customer side and to centtralize client pool on oslo cache
instead rise technical debt on the whole openstack by duplicating
these uses.

Change-Id: I2c6355d9e116408d96c53a29175bc0798f775722

commit_message:
Ignore new 'sys' mysql database by default

Mysql 8.0 has a new database 'sys' [1] that should be ignored by
trove by default.

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/sys-schema.html

Change-Id: Ie2b60e36bd9e20bb55b36d3c6b21e9ff1dc56fde

messages: [{'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-06-18 08:38:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-06-19 05:24:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3031, 'date': '2019-06-19 06:59:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6732, 'date': '2019-06-24 06:23:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-18 08:38:26.000000000', 'message': 'Use newer style mysql syntax for users/passwords

The sytax used for creating users and setting passwords
was deprecated in mysql 5.7 and is not valid in mysql 8.0. [1]

Change to use CREATE USER to create users as opposed
to creating users with GRANT syntax.

Setting passwords also does not use the PASSWORD keyword
anymore. [2]

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/grant.html
[2] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/set-password.html

Change-Id: I0387238ec434073f95dd76f13f1f40c7cec8d1eb
'}, {'created': '2019-06-19 05:24:30.000000000', 'message': 'Use newer style mysql syntax for users/passwords

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/grant.html

Change-Id: I0387238ec434073f95dd76f13f1f40c7cec8d1eb

commit_message:
Use newer style mysql syntax for users/passwords

The sytax used for creating users and setting passwords
was deprecated in mysql 5.7 and is not valid in mysql 8.0. [1]

Change to use CREATE USER to create users as opposed
to creating users with GRANT syntax.

Setting passwords also does not use the PASSWORD keyword
anymore. [2]

[1] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/grant.html
[2] https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/set-password.html

Change-Id: I0387238ec434073f95dd76f13f1f40c7cec8d1eb

You're right, I'll separate the disk TSI change."}, {'account_id': 26733, 'date': '2019-06-05 21:24:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-06 08:45:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

(1 comment)

Looking at the InfluxDB config files, we have two:

influxdb.conf        <- legacy
influxdb-1.0.0.conf  <- one in use at the moment

There is some logic in monasca-api/devstack/plugin.sh which switches between the two config files depending on the version of InfluxDB.

My preference is to remove the logic for switching between the two config files (remove support for InfluxDB < 1.0.0) and have a single config file called influxdb.conf for this new version.'}, {'account_id': 30438, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:41:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 30438, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:47:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 30438, 'date': '2019-06-06 09:47:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Looking at the InfluxDB config files, we have two:
 > 
 > influxdb.conf        <- legacy
 > influxdb-1.0.0.conf  <- one in use at the moment
 > 
 > There is some logic in monasca-api/devstack/plugin.sh which
 > switches between the two config files depending on the version of
 > InfluxDB.
 > 
 > My preference is to remove the logic for switching between the two
 > config files (remove support for InfluxDB < 1.0.0) and have a
 > single config file called influxdb.conf for this new version.

PS8 removes <= v1.0.0 config version and logic in plugin.sh.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-06 10:00:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 30438, 'date': '2019-06-06 10:06:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 17669, 'date': '2019-06-06 10:15:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

Thanks Isaac, this looks good to me, let's see what CI says.

commit_message:
Upgrade InfluxDB to latest release (v1.7.6)

Updated default config to use InfluxDB v1.7.6.
This appears to work, at least for viewing
metrics, persisting them, and some CLI commands.
Updated influxdb.conf to bring in line with sample
config.
Drops support for configs of older versions.

Story: 2005624
Task: 30877
Co-Authored-By: Isaac Prior <isaac@stackhpc.com>
Change-Id: Ib73151e6e7d0934303c9e801bb018bc22f1716ae

commit_message:
Correct error messages on create and update router form

The name is not required, so data["name"] may be empty.
When data["name"] is empty, get the id value.
This patch correct error messages on create and update form

Change-Id: I9d5eebf65501c5e182a9a135c97461ff3fcf57e7

It would be nice to write a functional test for this one but we can follow up :)'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-02-01 14:09:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> It would be nice to write a functional test for this one but we can
 > follow up :)

I thought about how to write functional tests but, I think it's tricky. Since we are just using a method from ovsdbapp I think the tests would be better to be on that repository actually. What u think ?"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-02-01 16:48:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

This probably won't hurt anything, I'm just not sure there is any code that actually *uses* nested transactions other than the one line that the read-only ovsdbapp patch was written to handle. ovn_client, for example, explicitly passes transactions to functions. So I wouldn't expect this patch to actually have any effect."}, {'account_id': 6854, 'date': '2019-02-04 06:23:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2019-02-05 11:14:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-02-05 11:20:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-02-05 14:34:04.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-02-05 14:34:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 17776, 'date': '2019-03-12 08:07:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

The patch is still required, I guess'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-03-12 19:51:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

It's not really required. There won't be any change in existing behavior with the patch because there are no longer any nested transactions in networking-ovn. It might be worth just making it possible in ovsdbapp itself to opt out of automatic nesting if it isn't desired. I lean toward the real solution being to just not nest transactions if you don't want transactions to be nested. :) But I am not opposed to it being configurable at the ovsdbapp level."}, {'account_id': 23804, 'date': '2019-03-13 09:41:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

Agreed with Terry.
@Lucas, please let us know if you still feel this is required as I know you're dealing with something related"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-03-13 09:45:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

> Agreed with Terry.
 > @Lucas, please let us know if you still feel this is required as I
 > know you're dealing with something related

Sure, yeah it's not really required as Terry said. I also believe that we don't have any nested transactions atm (but haven't fully validated it). In any case, I left this patch up more to gather some comments around this problem, we can abandon it now I suppose.

I still would like to see a way to opt out of nested transactions because I think that the code is a bit obscure as is now unless u know how the lib works internally (e.g create_transaction() is non nested vs transaction() *can* be nested)"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-03-13 09:45:47.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-20 15:43:32.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

I keep seeing problems with the nested transactions at http://logs.openstack.org/49/666549/1/check/networking-ovn-tempest-dsvm-ovs-master/a5b5b4e/controller/logs/screen-q-svc.txt.gz?level=ERROR

Restoring'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:20:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Does this patch fix those errors, though? I'd be surprised since the KeyError raised means that we aren't actually doing a nested transaction--the thread-id isn't found and the KeyError is expected. It looks like something else happened during the processing of that exception. Or am I reading that traceback wrong?"}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

It looks like during the KeyError processing a DbRemoveCommand was called and in Row.__getattr__ we have an issue which it looks like you actually fixed in a subsequent OVS version.

https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/commit/f192ba279e9c7d378f348017281b14f1585e0eaa'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-20 19:48:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:27:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> Does this patch fix those errors, though? I'd be surprised since
 > the KeyError raised means that we aren't actually doing a nested
 > transaction--the thread-id isn't found and the KeyError is
 > expected. It looks like something else happened during the
 > processing of that exception. Or am I reading that traceback wrong?

It seems to be two different exceptions there, 1 from the nested dict not being able to find the thread-id and the one from the "del dmap" which was fixed long ago but the python module hasn't been released yet ? 

I will try to ask for a new release upstream'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:28:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

If you look at the new logs, the thread-id error is no longer seen with this patch: http://logs.openstack.org/07/633707/8/check/networking-ovn-tempest-dsvm-ovs-master/cb9181b/controller/logs/screen-q-svc.txt.gz?level=ERROR#_Jun_20_20_22_00_178737'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-21 08:55:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

recheck

strange timeout http://logs.openstack.org/07/633707/8/check/networking-ovn-tempest-dsvm-ovs-release/14af5bb/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-06-20_22_57_39_498406'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-06-22 04:36:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

The thread I'd error isn't an error without the patch either. It's supposed to happen it's just that there is another exception that happens during the exception handling for the thread id looking failure which is expected and normally handled."}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-22 08:44:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

> The thread I'd error isn't an error without the patch either. It's
 > supposed to happen it's just that there is another exception that
 > happens during the exception handling for the thread id looking
 > failure which is expected and normally handled.

It could be, can we get a new release of the "ovs" library that would include that fix ?'}, {'account_id': 5756, 'date': '2019-06-23 15:55:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I released a 2.11.0 version a few days ago, does that work?'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-23 15:59:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

recheck

Thanks terry, let's see o/"}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-06-24 08:01:02.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Nice, thanks for the release terry. I don't see the nested errors anymore o/"}]

Change-Id: I40c96a07260ae3f985be5f9d3aeabd2f35b0430f

'}, {'created': '2019-01-30 10:53:50.000000000', 'message': 'Do not allow for nested transactions in OVNClient

The ovsdbapp library have two methods to create new transactions the
"transaction()" and "create_transaction()". The former will allow for
nested transactions, that means that one transaction can be started in a
different part of the code and subsequent transactions (within the same
thread) will use that already started transaction and append the OVS
commands to it.

Nested is a good optmization because it will minimize the number of
commits but, I believe it have to be well thought out to avoid problems
with that approach (we have faced a few in the past due to that
behavior).

This patch is changing the OVNClient code to not rely on nested
transactions by default and instead make it one atomic to avoid
undesirable behaviors. If we see the need, we could extend the
_transaction method from OVNClient in the future to support nested
transactions (as parameter) and use it where we see fit.

Change-Id: I40c96a07260ae3f985be5f9d3aeabd2f35b0430f
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-01-30 14:27:37.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid nested transactions from ovsdbapp

commit_message:
Avoid nested transactions from ovsdbapp

The ovsdbapp library have two methods to create new transactions the
"transaction()" and "create_transaction()". The former will allow for
nested transactions, that means that one transaction can be started in a
different part of the code and subsequent transactions (within the same
thread) will use that already started transaction and append the OVS
commands to it.

Nested is a good optmization because it will minimize the number of
commits but, I believe it have to be well thought out to avoid problems
with that approach (we have faced a few in the past due to that
behavior).

This patch is changing the OvsdbNbOvnIdl code to not rely on
nested transactions by default and instead make it one atomic to
avoid undesirable behaviors. If we see the need, we could extend the
transaction() method from OvsdbNbOvnIdl in the future to support nested
transactions (as parameter) and use it where we see fit.

Change-Id: I40c96a07260ae3f985be5f9d3aeabd2f35b0430f
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 15:29:00.000000000', 'message': "Don't exclude python bytecode files in dashboards

If these files are excluded from the rpm install then modified bytecode
files will remamin on disk on uninstall and cause unexpected behavior in
horizon. Remove these from the exclude list.

NOTE: openstack/freezer-web-ui is excluded as it hasn't existed in
stable/rocky yet.

Change-Id: Ib03f38285c3de377d4c71de4ed7feb1bfa919a35
(cherry picked from commit bee43edca5657f416de8a0a78ef6e3dfcbcd73e8)
"}]
commit_message:
Don't exclude python bytecode files in dashboards

If these files are excluded from the rpm install then modified bytecode
files will remamin on disk on uninstall and cause unexpected behavior in
horizon. Remove these from the exclude list.

NOTE: openstack/freezer-web-ui is excluded as it hasn't existed in
stable/rocky yet.

Change-Id: Ib03f38285c3de377d4c71de4ed7feb1bfa919a35
(cherry picked from commit bee43edca5657f416de8a0a78ef6e3dfcbcd73e8)

(21 comments)

-1 for a few things, most of which are just mechanical:

* use is_hybrid_plug_enabled

* fix the rebase damage on that migration_p comment block

* add a unit test for the libvirt driver pass-through change

* The bigger issue I have is the concern that we could have a server with both ovs hybrid plugged ports and ports without that, which would mean we could be building events to wait for which aren't going to come as a result of the port binding change - but if they will come because we're changing port binding host, then why even filter on ovs hybrid plug at all? Remember the original discussion around this was we expect all port binding changes to generate an event (but vif plugging doesn't always generate an event without an accompanying port binding change). But Sean changed your mind on all that to narrow this down to just OVS hybrid ports, but then shouldn't our list of events be only for the OVS hybrid plugged ports? Probably a question for Sean."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-10 16:05:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-06-10 17:20:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

(10 comments)

i have put some connect comment " with ... and read order numbers e.g. 0.)" of how we can maybe simplfy this as well as handeling both the hybrid_plug case and the sriov case.

the neutron backend  specific logic is moved to nova.network.modle.Vif

int a new function wait_in_manger which we might want to call
revert_wait_in_manger instead.

also both the manager and driver have a function to create teh set of network events we wait for that we could porably share as a cleanup after.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-06-10 17:31:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 23:

the -1 is because the mixed case is broken in the current version and i want use to agree on how to handel that before proceeding.

this does work for case 1 and 2, all vif events recived in manager and all vif event in driver but breaks if you have a mix of the two which will only happen if you are using kernel ovs with iptables + sriov port in the same vm.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-03-20 14:46:57.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Revert resize: wait for external events in compute manager

The previous patch stopped waiting for network-vif-plugged events when
doing a revert resize. This fixed the Neutron/libvirt driver race, in
which Neutron could send us the event before we had time to reach the
code in the libvirt driver that started listening for them, but
creates another problem. Now, an instance can boot without networking
because we didn't wait for Neutron to do its thing. This patch waits
for network-vif-plugged in the compute manager when we do the call to
Neutron.

Partial-bug: 1813789
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
"}, {'created': '2019-03-20 19:09:30.000000000', 'message': "[WIP] Revert resize: wait for external events in compute manager

The previous patch stopped waiting for network-vif-plugged events when
doing a revert resize. This fixed the Neutron/libvirt driver race, in
which Neutron could send us the event before we had time to reach the
code in the libvirt driver that started listening for them, but
creates another problem. Now, an instance can boot without networking
because we didn't wait for Neutron to do its thing. This patch waits
for network-vif-plugged in the compute manager when we do the call to
Neutron.

Partial-bug: 1813789
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4

'}, {'created': '2019-05-29 18:36:33.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Currently, when reverting a resized instance back to the source host,
the libvirt driver waits for vif-plugged events when spawning the
instance. If Neutron is configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will
send the vif-plugged event as soon as the Nova compute manager updates
the port binding to point to the source host. This causes the wait in
the libvirt driver to time out because the event is received before
Nova starts waiting for it. This patch checks the value of
ovs_hybrid_plug in the port details to decide when to wait for the
vif-plugged event. If hybrid plug is in use, wait in the compute
manager. Otherwise, wait in the libvirt driver.

Partial-bug: 1813789
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
'}, {'created': '2019-06-05 23:26:10.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Partial-bug: 1813789

'}, {'created': '2019-06-07 15:56:01.000000000', 'message': "Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

This patch checks the value of ovs_hybrid_plug in the port details to
decide when to wait for the vif-plugged event.  If hybrid plug is in
use, wait in the compute manager. Otherwise, wait in the libvirt
driver.

Partial-bug: 1813789
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4

"}, {'created': '2019-06-19 15:51:27.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. This type of events is hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a Neutron-wide setting, so for
a particular deployment, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing:
either all ports have them, or no ports have them. The only exception
is direct physical ports (ie, SRIOV). They will always have only
bind-time events. If an instances mixes OVS hybrid-plugged ports with
direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, right after port binding update, for bind-time
events, and/or in libvirt, right after plugging the VIFs, for
plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
'}, {'created': '2019-06-20 00:21:37.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second the agent must have completed configuring the port
on ovs. This involes asigning the port a local vlan for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
qos policies or other extentions such as service function chaining.

During the boot process we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emision of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid plug is used, binding the port to the
souce node fulfils the second condtion to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general a host will will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on the
same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, right after port binding update, for bind-time
events, and/or in libvirt, right after plugging the VIFs, for
plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4
'}, {'created': '2019-06-20 00:24:32.000000000', 'message': 'Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second the agent must have completed configuring the port
on ovs. This involes asigning the port a local vlan for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
qos policies or other extentions such as service function chaining.

During the boot process we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emision of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid plug is used, binding the port to the
souce node fulfils the second condtion to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general a host will will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, right after port binding update, for bind-time
events, and/or in libvirt, right after plugging the VIFs, for
plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4

commit_message:
Revert resize: wait for events according to hybrid plug

Since 4817165fc5938a553fafa1a69c6086f9ebe311af, when reverting a
resized instance back to the source host, the libvirt driver waits for
vif-plugged events when spawning the instance. When called from
finish_revert_resize() in the source compute manager, libvirt's
finish_revert_migration() does not pass vifs_already_plugged to
_create_domain_and_network(), making the latter use the default False
value.

When the source compute manager calls
network_api.migrate_instance_finish() in finish_revert_resize(), this
updates the port binding back to the source host. If Neutron is
configured to use OVS hybrid plug, it will send the vif-plugged event
immediately after completing this request. This happens before the
virt driver's finish_revert_migration() method is called. This causes
the wait in the libvirt driver to time out because the event is
received before Nova starts waiting for it.

The neutron ovs l2 agent sends vif-plugged events when two conditions
are met. First the port must be bound to the host managed by the
l2 agent and second, the agent must have completed configuring the
port on ovs. This involves assigning the port a local VLAN for tenant
isolation, applying security group rules if required and applying
QoS policies or other agent extensions like service function chaining.

During the boot process, we bind the port first to the host
then plug the interface into ovs which triggers the l2 agent to
configure it resulting in the emission of the vif-plugged event.
In the revert case, as noted above, since the vif is already plugged
on the source node when hybrid-plug is used, binding the port to the
source node fulfils the second condition to send the vif-plugged event.

Events sent immediately after port binding update are hereafter known
as "bind-time" events. For ports that do not use OVS hybrid plug,
Neutron will continue to send vif-plugged events only when Nova
actually plugs the VIF. These types of events are hereafter known as
"plug-time" events. OVS hybrid plug is a per agent setting, so for
a particular host, bind-time events are an all-or-nothing thing for the
ovs backend: either all VIF_TYPE=ovs ports have them, or no ovs ports
have them. In general, a host will only have one network backend.
The only exception to this is SR-IOV. SR-IOV is commonly deployed on
the same host as other network backends such as OVS or linuxbridge.
SR-IOV ports with VNIC_TYPE=direct-physical will always have only
bind-time events. If an instance mixes OVS ports with hybrid-plug=False
with direct physical ports, it will have both kinds of events.

This patch adds functions to the NetworkInfo model that return what
kinds of events each VIF has. These are then used in the migration
revert logic to decide when to wait for external events: in the
compute manager, when binding the port, for bind-time events,
and/or in libvirt, when plugging the VIFs, for plug-time events.

Closes-bug: 1832028
Co-Authored-By: Sean Mooney work@seanmooney.info
Change-Id: I51cdcae67be8c68a55bc939de4ea0aba2361dcc4

commit_message:
Blacklist bandit and update sphinx requirement

The change blacklists the buggy version of bandit (1.6.0) and syncs
sphinx dependency with global requirements. It caps python 2 since
sphinx 2.0 no longer supports Python 2.7.

Change-Id: I5d1ccfc502153e18ec0043c9eaa7cc6277edccb2
Story: 2005676
Task: 31053

commit_message:
Switch to using stestr

According to Openstack summit session [1] stestr is maintained
project to which all Openstack projects should migrate.
Let's switch it then.

[1] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/YVR-python-pti

Change-Id: I6f7d8766969bce4efd5c0bc36df2d583800e1e3e

[{'created': '2019-05-15 08:58:54.000000000', 'message': 'Remove the request_destination check in the scheduler

Since the patch `If7ea02df42d220c5042947efdef4777509492a0b` add the
`in_tree` support, the placement will return the resource providers
which matched the request_destination. So the request_destination check
in nova scheduler is useless.

Change-Id: I3dfa3258884137755e1e6ec973d263ba004fdddd
'}]
commit_message:
Remove the request_destination check in the scheduler

Since the patch `If7ea02df42d220c5042947efdef4777509492a0b` add the
`in_tree` support, the placement will return the resource providers
which matched the request_destination. So the request_destination check
in nova scheduler is useless.

Change-Id: I3dfa3258884137755e1e6ec973d263ba004fdddd

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

    Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
    and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
    developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

    People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
    concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
    and resubmit a new change-set.

    Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
    available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
    takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
    reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
    rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
    people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
    eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
    reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

    Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

    IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC

Two of the glance tests were creating temp files, leaving
/tmp/tmp* files around after each test run.  Use a fixture
instead so they are cleaned automatically.

commit_message:
Stop leaving temp files after unit test runs

Two of the glance tests were creating temp files, leaving
$TMPDIR/tmp* files around after each test run.  Use a fixture
instead so they are cleaned automatically.

Change-Id: I6b6d1cc01f900067cffa9ea8d4682e33c533bb24

[{'created': '2019-06-05 01:52:31.000000000', 'message': 'spec for multi-region container management

1. What is the problem ?
   Lack of implementation of container management in multi-region scenario.

2. What is the solution for the problem ?
   Write this spec to discribe how to implement the container management in the Tricircle multi-region scenario.

Change-Id: Iec0102656168e2d721cf2c0ec6d776e3aed881d6
Signed-off-by: XuShimin <948026069@qq.com>

commit_message:
spec for multi-region container management

1. What is the problem ?
   Lack of implementation of container management in multi-region scenario.

2. What is the solution for the problem ?
   Write this spec to discribe how to implement the container management in the Tricircle multi-region scenario.

Change-Id: Iec0102656168e2d721cf2c0ec6d776e3aed881d6
Signed-off-by: XuShimin <948026069@qq.com>

messages:
[{'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-06 03:19:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-06 08:45:42.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-06 15:39:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

Soft -1 for more details in the commit message. The commit message explains what the change is doing but not really why which I think is important information.'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-10 08:15:03.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-10 08:20:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-11 13:41:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

Some questions inline. This will side-step the issue but I'd like to know why instance.create.end won't hit the same problem because of that ModelRoot code which seems like it could be more robust to the entry not existing in the model (avoid the KeyError or at least don't traceback the KeyError)."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-11 16:15:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-12 07:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-12 19:34:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-12 19:39:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-13 08:45:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-06-20 08:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-21 01:39:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 29911, 'date': '2019-06-21 09:10:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

It makes sense to ignore notifcations when the ComputeNode is in state building. I think this patch implements this well.

The handling of instance.create.end and the prevention of KeyError(s) still need to be improved but we should do that in a different patch.

Maybe the handling of unmappable instances can be improved but as pointed out before: with the current way strategies are written it is not a problem.'}, {'account_id': 28748, 'date': '2019-06-22 08:07:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21692, 'date': '2019-06-24 03:18:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
check instance state for instance.update

In the process of creating an instance, Nova will emit an
instance.update notification with 'building' state.
This will cause a KeyError exception because this instance
isn't in Watcher datamodel.
So we should ignore the notification instance.update with
'building' state.

Closes-Bug: #1832154

Change-Id: I950eec50d2cee38bd22c47a70ae6f88bbf049080

commit_message:
extend libvirt video model support

- This change extends the VideoModel field object to allow 3 new values
  (virtio, gop, none)
- This change makes the libvirt driver use ALL tuple from the
  nova.fields.VideoModel object instead of declaring a second
  tuple inline for validation.
- This change allows the virtio video model to now be used
  for all architectures when explicitly requested via the
  hw_video_model image metadata property
- This change introduces unit tests and a release note
  for the new capablities.

Change-Id: I2830ccfc81cfa9654cfeac7ad5effc294f523552
Implements: blueprint libvirt-video-device-models

hmm. That means swift logs won't be rotated at all...
I'd rather mount its log dir into the logrotate_crond container."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2019-06-21 11:02:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Don't create symlink for swift container logs

logrotate 3.14.0 silently ignores all files when
there is a broken symlink in the container.

Change-Id: I52a74c7b5473340e2afd240d7d6af9ad5bc97544
Closes-Bug: #1833690

commit_message:
Deprecate the Nginx data store

This feature is no longer needed since ironic-inspector supports
storing data in the database, which is a better supported approach.

This patch does not provide any migration and expects the operators
to do it using the ironic-inspector tooling.

Change-Id: I6f18b3a64d6df9354c3f04a588240f9ae3228d7c

subject: Force --hostonly when regenerating the initramfs
messages: [{'account_id': 30126, 'date': '2019-06-22 07:03:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 30126, 'date': '2019-06-22 09:21:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\ncheck-rdo'}, {'account_id': 20172, 'date': '2019-06-23 20:32:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-22 07:03:33.000000000', 'message': 'Force --hostonly when regenerating the initramfs

The dracut-config-generic package (sometimes installed by default in
the overcloud image) provides a configuration file that turns off the
host-specific initramfs generation with dracut:

$ cat /usr/lib/dracut/dracut.conf.d/02-generic-image.conf
hostonly="no"

The result is that the generated initrams does not contain:

- /etc/systemd/journald.conf
- /etc/systemd/system.conf
- /etc/hostname
- /etc/machine-id
- /etc/vconsole.conf
- /etc/locale.conf
- /etc/modules-load.d/*.conf
- /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
- /etc/sysctl.conf

Especially problematic is the absence of sysctl.conf when ipv6 is
disabled via "KernelDisableIPv6: 1" because we end up half-disabling
ipv6 and services like rpbcind end up in failed state.

Original issue: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1830574

This commit builds on top of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661528/
adding the '--hostonly' option to dracut so to bypass 'hostonly="no"'
eventually contained in the default config file.

Change-Id: Ia4a39721268fe9bb0fdcc8bf4eb148263d4df46e
(cherry picked from commit 392eacb092d28094196f026acc70aead4d502060)
'}]
commit_message:
Force --hostonly when regenerating the initramfs

The dracut-config-generic package (sometimes installed by default in
the overcloud image) provides a configuration file that turns off the
host-specific initramfs generation with dracut:

$ cat /usr/lib/dracut/dracut.conf.d/02-generic-image.conf
hostonly="no"

The result is that the generated initrams does not contain:

- /etc/systemd/journald.conf
- /etc/systemd/system.conf
- /etc/hostname
- /etc/machine-id
- /etc/vconsole.conf
- /etc/locale.conf
- /etc/modules-load.d/*.conf
- /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
- /etc/sysctl.conf

Especially problematic is the absence of sysctl.conf when ipv6 is
disabled via "KernelDisableIPv6: 1" because we end up half-disabling
ipv6 and services like rpbcind end up in failed state.

Original issue: https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1830574

This commit builds on top of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/661528/
adding the '--hostonly' option to dracut so to bypass 'hostonly="no"'
eventually contained in the default config file.

Change-Id: Ia4a39721268fe9bb0fdcc8bf4eb148263d4df46e
(cherry picked from commit 392eacb092d28094196f026acc70aead4d502060)

commit_message:
Only register dynamic pool options when running designate-manage

We only need to load this code path when converting an old designate
configuration (pre-mitaka) into a pools.yaml file.

Change-Id: Ia9587880ca2428c0b3af074f0cb2a873859685ec

commit_message:
Finalized centralization of configuration

This patch removes get_cfg_opts from the plugin class,
and moves all configuration directly into designate.conf.

There are no changes in the generated configuration due
to this patch.

Finally, this complets the blueprint to centralize all
configuration, and is a follow up to this patch
I3be68bf294157631a9bac128df0841220020de96

blueprint centralize-config-designate

commit_message:
Remove deprecated arguments in db sync command

Remove deprecated optional argument '--version'
in the following commands.

* nova-manage db sync
* nova-manage api_db sync

Change-Id: I7795e308497de66329f288b43ecfbf978d67ad75
